title: Feasible climate mitigation - Nature Climate Change

last_post.content:
The transformative changes needed to tackle the climate crisis are happening far too slowly. We argue in Nature Climate Change that a more serious scientific and practical treatment of #feasibility is long overdue.

Feasibility analyses are key to identifying which mitigation initiatives can most effectively change the actions of target actors now and to understanding how to increase the feasibility of transformative initiatives over time.

Free link: rdcu.be/c16zK

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41558-022-01563-7

title: Predicting Topological Quantum Phase Transition via Multipartite Entanglement from Dynamics

last_post.content: Today's #arXivsummary: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13252 by Lakkaraju et. al. Authors show that the non-linearly perturbed Toric code undergoes a quantum phase from a topological phase to a a paramagnetic phase via tuning the nonlinear perturbation parameter. Loschmidt echo & time-averaged multipartite entanglement may determine whether initial state belongs to topological phase or not. #CondMat #StrEl #arXiv_2212_13251

title: Division Algebras and Quantum Theory

last_post.content:
Then I turned to the three-fold way and ten-fold way. The 'three-fold way' is Dyson's term for a classification of irreducible group representations in terms of the real numbers, complex numbers and quaternions. I explained it here:

https://arxiv.org/abs/1101.5690

The 'ten-fold way' is a fancier version, popular in condensed matter physics, that involves the 10 'super division algebras'. I explained it here:

https://math.ucr.edu/home/baez/tenfold.html

but I want to dig deeper.

(3/n)

title: Classical and quantum structuralism

last_post.content:
While ZX-calculus is key to pictorial quantum (cf Picturing Quantum Processes & coming Quantum in Pictures), equally important is graphical calculus for classical-quantum interaction. It's there that spiders first appeared, then yielding ZX-calculus.

https://arxiv.org/abs/0904.1997

title: https://doi.org/10.1162/opmi_a_00064

last_post.content:
Our new research shows how Chinese characters have evolved to become *more* complex over the past 3600 years. This is cool because for the last three centuries scholars have assumed the exact opposite. There are even explanatory myths accounting for character simplification going back to the Han dynasty (200 BCE-200 CE)

Also cool: the study was led by Simon Jerome Han while he was an *undergraduate* at the University of Melbourne.

The Conversation article is here: https://theconversation.com/most-assume-writing-systems-get-simpler-but-3-600-years-of-chinese-writing-show-its-getting-increasingly-complex-194732
The original research is here: https://doi.org/10.1162/opmi_a_00064

title: The imprints of primordial non-gaussianities on large-scale structure: scale dependent bias and abundance of virialized objects

last_post.content:
Dec 27 - Scale Dependent Bias (‘07)

https://arxiv.org/abs/0710.4560

Local non-Gaussianity changes the formation galaxies, resembling a violation of the equivalence principle. Through this effect, galaxy surveys like SPHEREx will improve measurements of this parameter by a factor of 10.

title: Factoring integers with sublinear resources on a superconducting quantum processor

last_post.content: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.12372 sure does spend a lot of space not mentioning the expected number of circuit shots it requires. It's critical to the entire premise of the paper to have a small bound on this number, and as far as I can tell they just don't talk about it. Very bad sign.

title: Large Language Models Encode Clinical Knowledge

last_post.content:
Large Language Models Encode Clinical Knowledge

Flan-PaLM achieves SotA accuracy on the proposed MultiMedQA MCQ dataset (MedQA, MedMCQA, PubMedQA, MMLU clinical topics), including 67.6% on USMLE questions, surpassing prior SotA by over 17%.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13138

title: https://doi.org/10.1093/aje/kwac137

last_post.content:
If you subscribe to the common trope that you should avoid "causal language," I strongly recommend getting all the way to the very final two paragraphs in the discussion of this paper.

There is a big plot twist there, and it might change your mind.

But to understand the potentially counterintuitive conclusion, you really really need to understand the framing and methods.

AJE pub: https://doi.org/10.1093/aje/kwac137
Near identical preprint version: https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.08.25.21262631

title: A non-constructive proof of the Four Colour Theorem

last_post.content:
This new claimed proof of the 4-color theorem is short, interesting, but problematic:

https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09835

The basic strategy is simple, as explained by @highergeometer:

"given a map L that isn't 4-colourable, then all but an exponentially small (in # edges) proportion of graphs are not 4-colourable, because they contain L. But the proportion of 4-colourable graphs has a lower bound proportional to # edges."

But there may be problems. Maybe you can help with a really simple one!

(1/n)

title: journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/...

last_post.content:
Why do overall gender/racial/etc disparities in the follow network matter? Social media attention:
- improves job prospects
- gets academics more citations (& money/promotions etc)
- shapes the careers of journalists

And despite claims that Twitter was an equalizer, it concentrated attention inequalities on average.

See Usher & Holcomb on this: https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/1940161218781254?casa_token=xFnipMcj3MkAAAAA%3ApXnzxTyfzdyXDcbAdK3wMLV7IWXw6h-n6ODeBW9d8RnNpekXbKGx_CF-l7M4P3xjZsDsRK-gbKYEQA
